greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: A(n,k) is the n-th derivative of f_k at x=1, and f_k is the k-th of all functions that are representable as x^x^...^x with m>=1 x's and parentheses inserted in all possible ways; square array A(n,k), n>=0, k>=1, read by antidiagonals.
comment: A000081(m) distinct functions are representable as x^x^...^x with m>=1 x's and parentheses inserted in all possible ways.  Some functions are representable in more than one way, the number of valid parenthesizations is A000108(m-1).  The f_k are ordered, such that the number m of x's in f_k is a nondecreasing function of k.  The exact ordering is defined by the algorithm below.
The list of functions f_1, f_2, ... begins:
link: Alois P. Heinz, Antidiagonals n = 0..140, flattened
maple: T:= proc(n) T(n):=`if`(n=1, [x], map(h-> x^h, g(n-1$2))) end:
f:= proc() local i, l; i, l:= 0, []; proc(n) while n>
nops(l) do i:= i+1; l:= [l[], T(i)[]] od; l[n] end
A:= (n, k)-> n!*coeff(series(subs(x=x+1, f(k)), x, n+1), x, n):
mathematica: g[n_, i_] := g[n, i] = If[i == 1, {x^n}, Flatten @ Table[ Table[ Table[ Product[T[i][[w[[t]] - t + 1]], {t, 1, j}]*v, {v, g[n - i*j, i - 1]}], {w, Subsets[ Range[ Length[T[i]] + j - 1], {j}]}], {j, 0, n/i}]];
f[n_] := Module[{i = 0, l = {}}, While[n > Length[l], i++; l = Join[l, T[i]]]; l[[n]]];
A[n_, k_] := n! * SeriesCoefficient[f[k] /. x -> x+1, {x, 0, n}];
Table[Table[A[n, 1+d-n], {n, 0, d}], {d, 0, 12}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Nov 08 2019, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
xref: Number of distinct values taken for m x's by derivatives n=1-10: A000012, A028310, A199085, A199205, A199296, A199883, A215796, A215971, A216062, A216403.
results.author: _Alois P. Heinz_, Aug 21 2012
